   normal S1, S2. Harsh [**5-14**] decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the
   right sternal border and on the clavicle; radiating to carotids, apex,
   and back.  Mild, lift. No S3 or S4.
   LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were
   unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or
   rhonchi.

   palpation. No abdominial bruits.

   SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:25.5/58.3/2.5, Differential-Neuts:85.1 %,
   Lymph:11.6 %, Mono:2.0 %, Eos:1.1 %, Ca++:8.9 mg/dL, Mg++:1.9 mg/dL,
   PO4:3.3 mg/dL
   CXR:  FINDINGS: Right internal jugular catheter terminates in proximal
   superior vena cava with no evidence of pneumothorax. There has been
   previous median sternotomy and aortic valve replacement. Aortic contour
   is unchanged compared to the previous radiograph of [**2140-3-10**].
   Heart remains enlarged, and
   there is a persistent area of nonspecific scarring adjacent to the left
   heart border. No pleural effusions are evident on this single
   projection. Incidental note is made of disruption of the lowest sternal
   wire.
   Head MRI: No evidence for aneurysm. Stable parenchymal atrophy in right
   parietal lobe.
   CT/CTA: Chest/Abdomen:
   1. Post-surgical changes with aortic graft and aortic valve prosthesis.
   2. Ascending aorta measures up to 5.9 cm in diameter.
   3. Cardiomegaly.
   4. Small left pleural effusion.
   5. Left basilar consolidation/atelectasis.
   6. Splenomegaly.
   7. Small amount of free fluid in the pelvis.
   8. No CT evidence for aortoenteric fistula
   CXR this AM: Pending
   Assessment and Plan
   28 yo with h/o aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, AVR x 2
   presenting with enterococcal bacteremia causing dehiscence of aortic
   valve replacement ring/right fibrous trigone, in the setting of
   profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, that has now
   stabilized s/p 10 units PRBC.
   .
   #Endocarditis: Likely embolic phenomena to L foot and L eye and
   possible abscess in fibrous trigone. Patient with dental filling
   replacement in [**Month (only) 1563**], even though patient took antibiotics, he started
   to feel increasingly tired some time after this procedure. Since
   patient denies IVDU, it is likely the dental procedure is the source of
   his enterococcus bacteremia. He is currently hemodynamically stable,
   although he is complaining of numbness in left lower extremity.
   Avoiding gentamicin given Hx of ototoxicity.
   - ID Consulting and appreciate recs
   - Will continue Ceftriaxone and Ampicllin per ID recs
   - ESR/CRP
   - BCx pending
   - MRI/MRA of Brain to rule out acute event; full report pending
   - Contact [**Name (NI) **] from OSH to check on sterile placement of line.  If
   not sterile consider EJ.
   #Aortic Valve Replacement: Patient with dehiscent aortic valve in the
   right fibrous trigone, likely due to a lost stitch. Patient
   hemodynamicaly stable.
   -CT surgery following and appreciate recs.
   -Start Metoprolol 25 mg [**Hospital1 **] to keep HR < 70. Reducing sheer force.
   -Continue Heparin gtt
   -Hold carvidolol and warfarin
   -TTE today
   -CTA of Chest/CXR PA/Lateral; full report pending
   #Anemia: Most likely [**3-12**] hemolysis though ? whether pt. had some GI
   bleed as dyspnea got acutely worse, retic count at OSH was
   inappropriate to chronic process and INR was supratherpeutic.
   - CT aorta r/o aortoenteric fistula
   - retic count in am pending
   - Metoprolol to decrease shear stress
   - Tx Hct <21 as no Hx CAD
   # Suspected L foot embolic disease: Foot appears warm and well perfused
   currently. will monitor closely for signs of abscess.
   - LLE U/S pending
   - ABIs today with follow up with vascular.
   - Follow pulses
   CORONARIES: Cardiac Cath [**3-17**] showed clean coronaries. Patient did have
   a troponin leak of 0.37. This is likely secondary to demand ischemia
   secondary to profound anemia.
   -Will continue to monitor for signs of acute ischemia
   -Monitor Hct daily Transfuse <21 as no Hx CAD
   .
   #Hx of IVDU: Patient states he has not used IVDU since prior to his
   second surgery in [**2139**]. Patient on suboxone in outpatient
   -SW consult for support pending
   -Continue to monitor for signs of active heroin withdrawal
   - hepatitis C serology pending
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with h/o of CHF prior to AVR (SEVERE AI). Now, patient
   with no signs of fluid overload; EF on TTE in  [**2141-11-27**] (after AVR) was
   > 55% with normal filling pressures PCWP < 12.
   -Will continue to monitor
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient currently in NSR.
   -Will continue to monitor on telemetry for signs of AV block
    # ACUTE RENAL FAILURE:  Patient with an increase of creatinine from
   baseline of 0.8. OSH peaked at 1.9, on presentation here, 1.2. Likely
   due to pre-renal etiology-> hypotensive state in OSH
kidney function
   improving
   -Will follow with BMP
   -Caution with renally cleared drugs
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  Regular, Low sodium diet
   Glycemic Control: None
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2142-9-3**] 01:41 PM- Right IJ
   20 Gauge - [**2142-9-3**] 04:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Heparin gtt
   Stress ulcer:  Pantoprazole
   VAP:  not intubated
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Patient and parents
   Father [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9797**] (HCP)
   Mother [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9798**]
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: CCU for now, consider call out to floor in am

Summary:

The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and aortic valve replacement (AVR) x2, presenting with enterococcal bacteremia causing dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring and right fibrous trigone. He has profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, which has stabilized after 10 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC). The patient is currently hemodynamically stable, but complaining of numbness in his left lower extremity.

The patient has several potential medical complications:

1. Endocarditis: Likely embolic phenomena to the left foot and left eye, and possible abscess in the fibrous trigone.
2. Aortic Valve Replacement: Dehiscent aortic valve in the right fibrous trigone, likely due to a lost stitch.
3. Anemia: Most likely hemolysis, possibly with gastrointestinal bleed.
4. Suspected Left Foot Embolic Disease: Foot appears warm and well-perfused currently, but will be monitored closely for signs of abscess.
5. Coronaries: Cardiac catheterization showed clean coronaries, but the patient has a troponin leak, likely secondary to demand ischemia due to profound anemia.
6. Acute Renal Failure: Patient has an increase in creatinine from baseline, likely due to pre-renal etiology, and kidney function is improving.
7. Hepatitis C: Patient has a history of intravenous drug use (IVDU), and hepatitis C serology is pending.
8. PUMP: Patient has a history of chronic heart failure (CHF) prior to AVR, but is currently without signs of fluid overload.
9. RHYTHM: Patient is currently in normal sinus rhythm (NSR), but will be monitored for signs of AV block.
10. Hx of IVDU: Patient has a history of IVDU and is currently on suboxone for support.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. ID consulting and antibiotic recommendations.
2. Continued Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin.
3. ESR/CRP and blood cultures pending.
4. MRI/MRA of Brain to rule out acute event.
5. CT aorta to rule out aortoenteric fistula.
6. Metoprolol to decrease shear stress.
7. Heparin gtt to continue.
8. Hold carvidolol and warfarin.
9. TTE and CTA of Chest/CXR PA/Lateral pending.
10. SW consult for support pending.
11. Continue to monitor for signs of acute ischemia and active heroin withdrawal.
12. Hepatitis C serology pending.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male who underwent aortic valve replacement (AVR) and is currently being treated for mechanical AVR endocarditis. The patient has a history of recurrent endocarditis and has undergone AVR twice. He presented with enterococcal bacteremia, which led to dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring and right fibrous trigone.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamically stable
* Complaining of numbness in the left lower extremity
* Has a prosthetic aortic valve with a dehiscent ring and right fibrous trigone
* Has a small left pleural effusion and left basilar consolidation/atelectasis
* Has a small amount of free fluid in the pelvis
* Has a prosthetic aortic graft with an anastomotic pseudoaneurysm at the distal site
* Has a history of profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, which has now stabilized
* Has a WBC count of 8.8, Hct of 29.9, and platelet count of 243
* Has a creatinine level of 1.2, which is increasing due to pre-renal etiology
* Has a normal EF on TTE, but with mild paravalvular aortic regurgitation
* Has a history of CHF prior to AVR, but is currently not showing signs of fluid overload

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Endocarditis with embolic phenomena to the left foot and left eye, and possible abscess in the fibrous trigone
* Hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage
* Acute renal failure due to pre-renal etiology
* Aortic root abscess at the right fibrous trigone
* Anastomotic pseudoaneurysm at the distal site of the aortic graft
* Possible aortoenteric fistula
* Possible abscess in the left foot
* Possible acute ischemia due to demand ischemia secondary to profound anemia

The patient is currently being treated with Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin, and is also receiving Heparin to prevent thrombosis. He is also being monitored for signs of acute ischemia and has been started on Metoprolol to reduce shear stress. The patient's family has been informed of his condition and has been advised to monitor for signs of active heroin withdrawal.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and aortic valve replacement (AVR). He is currently in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to enterococcal bacteremia causing dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring and right fibrous trigone.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.5C, heart rate of 70 beats per minute, blood pressure of 108/66 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 29 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 99%, and he is receiving room air.

The patient's physical examination reveals a normal cardiac examination, with a harsh decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the right sternal border and on the clavicle. His lungs are clear, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.8 K/uL, hemoglobin of 10.3 g/dL, platelet count of 243 K/uL, and creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL. His electrolytes are within normal limits, and his glucose level is 103 mg/dL.

The patient's radiology studies show a small left pleural effusion and cardiomegaly on chest/abdomen computed tomography (CT) scan. His cardiac MRI shows no evidence of aneurysm or acute event.

The patient's diagnosis is likely embolic phenomena to the left foot and left eye, and possible abscess in the fibrous trigone. He is currently being treated with ceftriaxone and ampicillin, and his antibiotics will be continued per infectious disease (ID) consultant recommendations.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this condition include:

1. Septicemia: The patient's enterococcal bacteremia can lead to septicemia, which can cause organ failure and death.
2. Endocarditis: The patient's current diagnosis of endocarditis can lead to further valve damage, embolic phenomena, and abscess formation.
3. Aortic valve dysfunction: The dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring can lead to aortic valve dysfunction, which can cause heart failure and death.
4. Renal failure: The patient's current diagnosis of acute renal failure can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
5. Hemolytic anemia: The patient's hemolytic anemia can lead to anemia, jaundice, and hemolytic crisis.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's current diagnosis of sinus rhythm can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia.
7. Stroke: The patient's embolic phenomena to the left foot and left eye can lead to stroke, which can cause permanent neurological damage.
8. Sepsis: The patient's current diagnosis of sepsis can lead to multi-organ failure and death.

In conclusion, the patient's diagnosis is likely embolic phenomena to the left foot and left eye, and possible abscess in the fibrous trigone. He is currently being treated with antibiotics and is at risk for various medical complications, including septicemia, endocarditis, aortic valve dysfunction, renal failure, hemolytic anemia, cardiac arrhythmias, stroke, and sepsis.

   presenting with enterococcal bacteremia causing dehiscence of aortic
   valve replacement ring/right fibrous trigone, in the setting of
   profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, that has now
   stabilized s/p 10 units PRBC.
   .
   #Endocarditis: Likely embolic phenomena to L foot and L eye and
   possible abscess in fibrous trigone. Patient with dental filling
   replacement in [**Month (only) 1563**], even though patient took antibiotics, he started
   to feel increasingly tired some time after this procedure. Since
   patient denies IVDU, it is likely the dental procedure is the source of
   his enterococcus bacteremia. He is currently hemodynamically stable,
   although he is complaining of numbness in left lower extremity.
   Avoiding gentamicin given Hx of ototoxicity.
   - ID Consulting and appreciate recs
   - Will continue Ceftriaxone and Ampicllin per ID recs
   - ESR/CRP
   - BCx pending
   - MRI/MRA of Brain to rule out acute event; full report pending
   #Aortic Valve Replacement: Patient with dehiscent aortic valve in the
   right fibrous trigone, likely due to a lost stitch. Patient
   hemodynamicaly stable.
   -CT surgery following and appreciate recs
   -Start Metoprolol 12.5 mg [**Hospital1 **] to keep HR < 70. Goal is to increase
   filling time.
   -Continue Heparin gtt
   -Hold carvidolol and warfarin
   -TTE tomorrow
   -CTA of Chest/CXR PA/Lateral; full report pending
   #Anemia: Most likely [**3-12**] hemolysis though ? whether pt. had some GI
   bleed as dyspnea got acutely worse, retic count at OSH was
   inappropriate to chronic process and INR was supratherpeutic.
   - CT aorta r/o aortoenteric fistula
   - retic count in am pending
   - Metoprolol to decrease shear stress
   - Tx Hct <21 as no Hx CAD
   # Suspected L foot embolic disease: Foot appears warm and well perfused
   currently. will monitor closely for signs of abscess.
   - LLE U/S pending
   - Follow pulses
   CORONARIES: Cardiac Cath [**3-17**] showed clean coronaries. Patient did have
   a troponin leak of 0.37. This is likely secondary to demand ischemia
   secondary to profound anemia.
   -Will continue to monitor for signs of acute ischemia
   -Monitor Hct daily Transfuse <21 as no Hx CAD
   .
   #Hx of IVDU: Patient states he has not used IVDU since prior to his
   second surgery in [**2139**]. Patient on suboxone in outpatient
   -SW consult for support pending
   -Continue to monitor for signs of active heroin withdrawal
   - hepatitis C serology pending
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with h/o of CHF prior to AVR (SEVERE AI). Now, patient
   with no signs of fluid overload; EF on TTE in  [**2141-11-27**] (after AVR) was
   > 55% with normal filling pressures PCWP < 12.
   -Will continue to monitor
   .
   # RHYTHM: Patient currently in NSR.
   -Will continue to monitor on telemetry for signs of AV block
    # ACUTE RENAL FAILURE:  Patient with an increase of creatinine from
   baseline of 0.8. OSH peaked at 1.9, on presentation here, 1.2. Likely
   due to pre-renal etiology-> hypotensive state in OSH
kidney function
   improving
   -Will follow with BMP
   -Caution with renally cleared drugs
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  Regular, Low sodium diet
   Glycemic Control: None

Summary:

The patient is a 28-year-old male who underwent aortic valve replacement (AVR) and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to mechanical AVR endocarditis. He has a history of recurrent endocarditis and has undergone AVR twice previously. The patient is currently hemodynamically stable, but has developed a left hip pain that is mildly tender to palpation. He has also complained of numbness in his left lower extremity.

The patient has been treated with antibiotics, including ceftriaxone and ampicillin, and is currently receiving heparin infusion to prevent thrombosis. His blood cultures are pending, and a brain MRI/MRA is planned to rule out an acute event.

The patient has a history of profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, which has stabilized after receiving 10 units of packed red blood cells. He also has a history of dental filling replacement, which is suspected to be the source of his enterococcus bacteremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Embolic phenomena: The patient's endocarditis may lead to embolic events, such as stroke or peripheral embolism.
2. Abscess formation: The patient's fibrous trigone may develop an abscess, which could lead to further complications.
3. Hemolytic anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further complications, such as cardiac dysfunction or respiratory failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, and he may develop acute renal failure.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac function may deteriorate, leading to cardiac failure or arrhythmias.
6. Neurological complications: The patient may develop neurological symptoms, such as seizures or stroke, due to his endocarditis or hemolytic anemia.
7. Infections: The patient may develop secondary infections, such as pneumonia or sepsis, due to his immunosuppressed state.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient may develop gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to his anemia or endocarditis.
9. Respiratory complications: The patient may develop respiratory failure due to his anemia or endocarditis.
10. Cardiac tamponade: The patient may develop cardiac tamponade due to his endocarditis or valvular damage.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and aortic valve replacement (AVR) x2. He presented with enterococcal bacteremia, which caused dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring and right fibrous trigone. He has been diagnosed with profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, which has now stabilized after receiving 10 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC).

The patient is currently hemodynamically stable, but he is complaining of numbness in his left lower extremity. He has a history of ototoxicity, so gentamicin is being avoided. The patient is being treated with Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin per ID recommendations. 

The patient's physical examination reveals a harsh decrescendo diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border, radiating to carotids, apex, and back. His lungs are clear, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 10.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 243 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 8.8 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Glucose: 103 mg/dL
* INR: 2.5
* PT: 58.3 seconds
* PTT: 25.5 seconds

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: Enlarged heart, persistent area of nonspecific scarring adjacent to the left heart border, and no pleural effusions.
* CT/CTA: Ascending aorta measures up to 5.9 cm in diameter, cardiomegaly, small left pleural effusion, left basilar consolidation/atelectasis, and small amount of free fluid in the pelvis.
* Head MRI: No evidence of aneurysm, stable parenchymal atrophy in the right parietal lobe.

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin per ID recommendations
* Monitoring for signs of abscess in the left foot
* Ordering an LLE ultrasound
* Monitoring pulses
* Continuing to monitor for signs of acute ischemia
* Transfusing PRBC as needed to maintain a hemoglobin level of 21 or greater
* Monitoring for signs of active heroin withdrawal
* Ordering hepatitis C serology

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Continued bacteremia and sepsis
* Embolic phenomena to the left foot and eye
* Possible abscess in the fibrous trigone
* Aortic valve dehiscence
* Hemolytic anemia
* Acute renal failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Ischemia
* Pulmonary edema
* Sepsis-induced cardiac failure

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Medical History:**

* The patient has a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and aortic valve replacement (AVR) twice.
* He has a history of severe aortic insufficiency (AI) prior to AVR and is currently hemodynamically stable.
* The patient has a history of intravenous drug use (IVDU) and is currently on suboxone for outpatient treatment.

**Current Condition:**

* The patient has dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring/right fibrous trigone, likely due to a lost stitch.
* He has enterococcal bacteremia, which is likely the source of his current condition.
* The patient has profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, which has now stabilized.
* He has numbness in his left lower extremity, which may be due to embolic phenomena.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Embolic phenomena to the left foot and eye, which may lead to abscess formation.
* Possible abscess in the fibrous trigone.
* Acute renal failure due to hypotension and decreased cardiac output.
* Cardiac tamponade due to dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring.
* Aortoenteric fistula due to dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring.
* Acute ischemia due to demand ischemia secondary to profound anemia.
* Active heroin withdrawal due to recent cessation of IVDU.
* Hepatitis C serology due to IVDU history.
* AV block due to cardiac catheterization.

**Plan:**

* Start Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin per ID recommendations.
* ESR/CRP, BCx, and MRI/MRA of Brain to rule out acute event.
* CT surgery following and appreciate recs.
* Start Metoprolol to keep HR < 70 and increase filling time.
* Continue Heparin gtt and hold carvidolol and warfarin.
* Monitor for signs of abscess in the left foot and fibrous trigone.
* Monitor for signs of acute ischemia and consider transfusion of blood products.
* Continue to monitor for signs of active heroin withdrawal and consider SW consult for support.
* Hepatitis C serology and consider antiviral treatment if positive.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male who underwent aortic valve replacement (AVR) and is currently in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to complications.

The patient has a history of recurrent endocarditis and has developed dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring/right fibrous trigone, which is causing enterococcal bacteremia. He has also developed profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, which has now stabilized.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring shows a stable condition with a blood pressure of 108/66 mmHg and a heart rate of 70 bpm.
* The patient is receiving Heparin Sodium infusion and other ICU medications.
* The patient's white blood cell count is 8.8 K/uL, and his platelet count is 243 K/uL.
* The patient's creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL, and his glucose level is 103 mg/dL.
* The patient's serum electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient's physical examination reveals no significant abnormalities, except for a palpable mass in the right fibrous trigone.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* ID consulting and ID recs for enterococcal bacteremia.
* Starting Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin per ID recs.
* ESR/CRP and BCx pending.
* MRI/MRA of Brain to rule out acute event.
* CT surgery following and appreciate recs.
* Starting Metoprolol 12.5 mg to keep HR < 70 and goal is to increase filling time.
* Continuing Heparin gtt.
* Holding carvidolol and warfarin.
* TTE tomorrow.
* CTA of Chest/CXR PA/Lateral.
* CT aorta to eval for aortoenteric fistula.
* Retic count in am.
* Metoprolol to decrease shear stress.
* Tx Hct <21 as no Hx CAD.
* LLE U/S and follow pulses.
* Coronary cath showed clean coronaries, but patient had a troponin leak of 0.37, which is likely secondary to demand ischemia secondary to profound anemia.
* Monitor Hct daily and transfuse <21 as no Hx CAD.
* SW consult for support.
* Continue to monitor for signs of active heroin withdrawal.
* Hepatitis C serology.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Endocarditis: likely embolic phenomena to L foot and L eye and possible abscess in fibrous trigone.
* Aortic valve replacement: dehiscent aortic valve in the right fibrous trigone, likely due to a lost stitch.
* Anemia: most likely 3-12 hemolysis though? whether pt. had some GI bleed as dyspnea got acutely worse, retic count at OSH was inappropriate to chronic process and INR was supratherpeutic.
* Suspected L foot embolic disease: foot appears warm and well perfused currently, will monitor closely for signs of abscess.
* Coronary disease: patient had a troponin leak of 0.37, which is likely secondary to demand ischemia secondary to profound anemia.
* Hepatitis C: patient has a history of IVDU and is on suboxone in outpatient.

The patient's treatment plan includes antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and close monitoring for signs of complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and AVR x2, currently admitted to the ICU due to enterococcal bacteremia causing dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring/right fibrous trigone, and profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage. The patient has undergone 10 units of PRBC transfusion, and his hemodynamic status is stable.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient is at risk of developing further endocarditis due to the dehiscent aortic valve replacement ring/right fibrous trigone, and the presence of enterococcal bacteremia.
2. Aortic Valve Replacement: The patient requires urgent surgery to replace the dehiscent aortic valve, and the timing of the surgery is pending ID consultation.
3. Hemolytic Anemia: The patient's hemolytic anemia is likely secondary to valvular damage, and it is essential to monitor his hemoglobin levels and transfuse if necessary.
4. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient's coronary cath showed clean coronaries, but he has a new wall motion abnormality on TTE, which may indicate emboli in the coronaries. He may require further evaluation and treatment for coronary artery disease.
5. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has increased, and he is at risk of developing acute renal failure due to pre-renal etiology. He requires close monitoring of his kidney function and cautious use of renally cleared drugs.
6. Infectious Process: The patient has a pending dental consultation to assess for infectious processes in his mouth, and he requires further evaluation and treatment for his enterococcal bacteremia.
7. Aortic Aneurysm: The patient's CT scan showed an ascending aorta measuring up to 5.9 cm in diameter, which may indicate an aortic aneurysm. He requires further evaluation and treatment for this condition.
8. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's TTE shows a new wall motion abnormality, and he may require further evaluation and treatment for cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac catheterization or CABG.

ICU Care:

The patient requires close monitoring in the ICU, including hemodynamic monitoring, respiratory support, and management of his antibiotics and other medications. He also requires regular assessment of his hemoglobin levels, kidney function, and cardiovascular status.

Summary:

The patient is a 28-year-old male who presented with enterococcal bacteremia, causing dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring and right fibrous trigone. He has a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and AVR. The patient is currently hemodynamically stable and is being treated with Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin. He has a severe left tibial disease and is at risk for embolic phenomena to the left foot and eye.

Medical Complications:

1. Aortic Valve Dehiscence: The patient has a dehiscent aortic valve replacement ring and right fibrous trigone, which is causing paravalvular regurgitation and hemolytic anemia.
2. Enterococcal Bacteremia: The patient has a severe enterococcal bacteremia, which is causing a systemic inflammatory response and hemolytic anemia.
3. Hemolytic Anemia: The patient has a severe hemolytic anemia, which is causing a decrease in hemoglobin levels and requiring transfusions.
4. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and is at risk for coronary emboli.
5. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has an acute increase in creatinine levels, which is likely due to a pre-renal etiology caused by hypotension.
6. Septic Shock: The patient is at risk for septic shock due to his severe bacteremia and inflammatory response.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient is at risk for cardiac arrest due to his aortic valve dehiscence and enterococcal bacteremia.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to his acute respiratory distress syndrome and potential for pneumonia.
3. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his enterococcal bacteremia and potential for spread of infection to other organs.
4. Organ Failure: The patient is at risk for organ failure due to his acute renal failure, hemolytic anemia, and potential for other organ dysfunction.

Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.
2. Monitor for signs of cardiac arrest, respiratory failure, and sepsis.
3. Continue to monitor hemoglobin levels and transfuse as necessary.
4. Consider coronary catheterization and CABG if coronary emboli are detected.
5. Monitor for signs of acute renal failure and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Consider MRI of the brain to rule out acute event.
7. Continue to monitor for signs of active heroin withdrawal and provide support as necessary.
8. Continue to monitor for signs of fluid overload and adjust treatment as necessary.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Patient Summary:**

The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and aortic valve replacement. He is currently admitted to the ICU with severe enterococcal bacteremia, dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring, and profound hemolytic anemia. The patient has undergone 10 units of packed red blood cell transfusion and is currently hemodynamically stable.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Septic Emboli:** The patient has a high risk of developing septic emboli due to his bacteremia and valve replacement. This can lead to complications such as stroke, myocardial infarction, and peripheral emboli.
2. **Aortic Valve Replacement Failure:** The dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring increases the risk of valve failure, which can lead to cardiac tamponade, shock, and death.
3. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing hemolysis, bleeding, and marrow suppression. This can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues and organs.
4. **Renal Failure:** The patient's creatinine levels have increased, and he is at risk of developing acute renal failure due to pre-renal etiology and hypotensive state.
5. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he is at risk of developing cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac tamponade.
6. **Infectious Complications:** The patient is at risk of developing infectious complications such as endocarditis, sepsis, and abscesses due to his bacteremia and valve replacement.
7. **Pulmonary Complications:** The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is at risk of developing pulmonary complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and respiratory failure.
8. **Gastrointestinal Complications:** The patient's anemia and hypovolemia may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding, nausea, and vomiting.
9. **Neurological Complications:** The patient is at risk of developing neurological complications such as stroke, seizures, and encephalopathy due to his bacteremia and septic emboli.

**Plan:**

1. Continue antibiotic therapy and monitor for signs of septic emboli.
2. Monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust therapy as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust therapy as necessary.
9. Consider consultation with cardiology, infectious disease, and vascular surgery services as necessary.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's progress and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that may arise:

**Patient Information**

* Age: 28 years old
* Chief Complaint: Enterococcal bacteremia, dehiscence of aortic valve replacement ring, and right fibrous trigone
* Medical History: Aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and AVR x 2
* Current Condition: Hemodynamically stable, but with significant hemolytic anemia, septic emboli, and anemia

**Current Issues**

* Enterococcal endocarditis: Patient has a high risk of septic emboli to the left foot and eye, and possibly abscess in the fibrous trigone
* Aortic Valve Replacement: Patient has a dehiscent aortic valve in the right fibrous trigone, likely due to a lost stitch
* Anemia: Patient has significant hemolytic anemia, which may be due to valvular damage or GI bleed
* Coronary Artery Disease: Patient has clean coronaries, but with a new wall motion abnormality on TTE, concerning for emboli in the coronaries
* L foot embolic disease: Patient has severe left tibial disease, and ABI shows decreased pulses on the left
* Acute Renal Failure: Patient has an increase in creatinine from baseline, likely due to pre-renal etiology and hypotensive state

**Potential Complications**

* Septic emboli to the left foot and eye
* Abscess in the fibrous trigone
* Hemolytic anemia exacerbation
* GI bleed
* Coronary artery occlusion or embolism
* Aortic valve failure
* Renal failure or worsening of acute renal failure
* Infection or abscess in the aortic graft or prosthesis
* Hemorrhage or bleeding complications from PICC line placement

**Plan**

* Continue dual antibiotic therapy for enterococcal endocarditis
* Monitor for signs of septic emboli, hemolytic anemia, and GI bleed
* Consider CABG at the same time as AVR
* Monitor Hct daily and transfuse if <21
* Start suboxone therapy for opioid dependence
* Monitor for signs of active heroin withdrawal
* Hepatitis C serology pending
* Plan for surgery in 2 weeks, with IV antibiotics continued during and after surgery
* Transfer to [**Hospital Ward Name 790**] today

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications may arise:

1. Septic Emboli: The patient has a history of endocarditis, and the recent MRI report shows interval development of small contrast-enhancing and hemorrhagic lesions along the cerebral hemispheres and left cerebellum, which may be cortical or leptomeningeal. This suggests that the patient is at risk for septic emboli, which can lead to severe complications such as stroke, brain abscess, or death.
2. Aortic Valve Dehiscence: The patient has a dehiscent aortic valve in the right fibrous trigone, likely due to a lost stitch. This can lead to aortic valve regurgitation, which can cause heart failure, arrhythmias, and even death.
3. Hemolytic Anemia: The patient has a hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, which has now stabilized after receiving 10 units of PRBC. However, the patient is at risk for further hemolysis, especially if the aortic valve dehiscence is not addressed.
4. L Foot Embolic Disease: The patient has severe left tibial disease, which is likely due to embolic disease. This can lead to tissue necrosis, gangrene, and even amputation.
5. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient has new wall motion abnormality on TTE, which is concerning for emboli in the coronaries. This can lead to acute coronary syndrome, heart failure, and even death.
6. Acute Renal Failure: The patient had a peak creatinine of 1.9 in OSH, which is likely due to pre-renal etiology and hypotensive state. The patient's creatinine has now returned to baseline, but the patient is at risk for further acute kidney injury.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is at risk for respiratory failure, especially if the patient's aortic valve dehiscence is not addressed.
8. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient has a history of aortic valve replacement and is at risk for cardiovascular complications such as aortic valve regurgitation, heart failure, and arrhythmias.

In terms of the patient's current condition, the patient is hemodynamically stable, but the patient's aortic valve dehiscence and hemolytic anemia need to be addressed urgently to prevent further complications. The patient's L foot embolic disease and coronary artery disease also need to be monitored closely to prevent further tissue damage and cardiac complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 28-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of endocarditis, likely caused by a dental procedure. He has a history of aortic valvuloplasty and recurrent endocarditis. The patient has been treated with antibiotics and has undergone aortic valve replacement. He is currently hemodynamically stable, but has developed septic emboli in his left foot, left eye, and cerebral hemispheres.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of hemolytic anemia, with a decreased hemoglobin level and increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. His cardiac enzymes are elevated, consistent with myocardial infarction.

The patient's physical examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur in the right sternal border, consistent with aortic regurgitation. His peripheral pulses are decreased on the left side, and his ankle-brachial index (ABI) shows severe left tibial disease.

Potential medical complications:

1. Septic emboli: The patient has developed septic emboli in his left foot, left eye, and cerebral hemispheres, which can lead to further complications such as gangrene, abscesses, or brain infarction.
2. Hemolytic anemia: The patient's hemolytic anemia can lead to further complications such as anemia, jaundice, and increased risk of infections.
3. Aortic regurgitation: The patient's aortic regurgitation can lead to further complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and increased risk of endocarditis.
4. Coronary artery disease: The patient's coronary artery disease can lead to further complications such as myocardial infarction, angina, and increased risk of heart failure.
5. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure can lead to further complications such as chronic kidney disease, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of infections.
6. Infective endocarditis: The patient's infective endocarditis can lead to further complications such as valve destruction, abscesses, and increased risk of mortality.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic therapy as directed by the infectious disease consultant.
2. Monitor the patient's hemoglobin levels and transfuse as necessary to maintain a hemoglobin level of at least 21.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and troponin levels to assess for signs of myocardial infarction.
4. Monitor the patient's peripheral pulses and ABI to assess for signs of peripheral artery disease.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust fluid management as necessary.
6. Consider performing a cardiac catheterization to assess for signs of coronary artery disease.
7. Consider performing a magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) of the patient's left foot to assess for signs of peripheral artery disease.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust pain management as necessary.
9. Consider performing a liver function test to assess for signs of liver damage.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluid management as necessary.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and aortic valve replacement (AVR). He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of endocarditis, likely caused by a dental procedure.

The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including:

1. Dehiscent aortic valve replacement ring/right fibrous trigone, which may lead to further embolic phenomena.
2. Profound hemolytic anemia secondary to valvular damage, which has stabilized after receiving 10 units of packed red blood cells.
3. Anemia likely due to patient bleeding with PICC line placement and marrow suppression from an active inflammatory state or hemolytic anemia.
4. Left foot embolic disease, with severe left tibial disease and occlusive arteries, which may require intervention.
5. Coronary artery disease, with a new wall motion abnormality on TTE, concerning for emboli in the coronaries.
6. Acute renal failure, likely due to pre-renal etiology and hypotensive state, which has resolved.
7. Hepatitis C serology negative.

The patient is currently hemodynamically stable, but the potential for further complications is high. The patient's condition requires close monitoring, and the following potential medical complications need to be considered:

1. Septic emboli to the left foot, left eye, coronary artery, and cerebral hemispheres.
2. Abscess in the fibrous trigone.
3. Further valvular damage, leading to hemolytic anemia and anemia.
4. Coronary artery disease, leading to myocardial infarction or ischemia.
5. Acute renal failure, requiring dialysis.
6. Hepatitis C infection, despite negative serology.
7. Pulmonary embolism, given the patient's history of deep vein thrombosis.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing Ceftriaxone and Ampicillin per ID recommendations.
2. Monitoring for signs of septic emboli, anemia, and coronary artery disease.
3. Surveillance TTE on Monday to assess for any changes in cardiac function.
4. Vascular/interventional consultation for left foot embolic disease.
5. Consideration of CABG at the same time as AVR.
6. Monitoring for signs of acute ischemia and transfusing for Hct <21.
7. Continued suboxone therapy for opioid dependence.
8. Monitoring for signs of active heroin withdrawal.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and aortic valve replacement (AVR) who presented with enterococcal bacteremia, dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring, and profound hemolytic anemia. He has been stabilized with 10 units of packed red blood cells and is currently hemodynamically stable. The patient has undergone a CT scan of the head, which showed interval development of small contrast-enhancing and hemorrhagic lesions along the cerebral hemispheres and left cerebellum, consistent with septic emboli. The patient also has occlusive arteries in the left foot, which is concerning for potential embolic disease.

Potential medical complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient is at risk for further embolic phenomena, including abscesses in the fibrous trigone, coronary artery, and cerebral hemispheres.
2. Septic emboli: The patient has already developed septic emboli in the cerebral hemispheres and left cerebellum, which may lead to further complications, such as stroke or cerebral edema.
3. Aortic valve replacement: The patient has a dehiscent aortic valve replacement ring, which may lead to further complications, such as valve failure or hemodynamic instability.
4. Anemia: The patient has profound hemolytic anemia, which may lead to further complications, such as heart failure or cardiac arrest.
5. Coronary artery disease: The patient has coronary artery disease, which may lead to further complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
6. Left foot embolic disease: The patient has occlusive arteries in the left foot, which may lead to further complications, such as gangrene or amputation.
7. Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which may lead to further complications, such as chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for endocarditis and septic emboli.
2. Monitor the patient's hemodynamic status closely and adjust therapy as needed.
3. Consider surgery to repair the dehiscent aortic valve replacement ring.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as necessary.
5. Consider coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) to address coronary artery disease.
6. Monitor the patient's left foot embolic disease and consider interventional procedures to improve perfusion.
7. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as necessary.

Note: The patient's medical history, laboratory results, and imaging studies are complex and require careful review and interpretation. The recommendations above are based on the information provided in the progress note and are subject to change based on further evaluation and management.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of aortic valvuloplasty, recurrent endocarditis, and awaiting aortic valve replacement (AVR). He presented with enterococcal bacteremia, causing dehiscence of the aortic valve replacement ring and right fibrous trigone, as well as profound hemolytic anemia.

The patient's current condition is stable, with no signs of septic shock. However, there are several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Septic emboli: The patient has developed septic emboli in the left foot, left eye, coronary artery, and cerebral hemispheres, which may lead to further complications such as infarction, abscesses, or septic shock.
2. Hemolytic anemia: The patient has developed hemolytic anemia, which may worsen if not managed properly. Close monitoring of hemoglobin levels and transfusion therapy may be necessary.
3. Aortic valve replacement: The patient's aortic valve is dehiscent, and AVR is planned. However, there is a risk of further complications such as bleeding, infection, or valve failure.
4. Coronary artery disease: The patient has developed new wall motion abnormality on TTE, which may be due to septic emboli in the coronaries. This may lead to further complications such as myocardial infarction or unstable angina.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Renal failure: The patient has developed acute renal failure, which may be due to pre-renal etiology and hypotensive state. Close monitoring of renal function and fluid balance is necessary to prevent further complications.
7. Infectious complications: The patient is at risk of developing further infectious complications, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or bloodstream infections.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient is at risk of developing further cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.

To mitigate these risks, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of septic shock, hemolytic anemia, aortic valve failure, coronary artery disease, anemia, renal failure, infectious complications, and cardiovascular complications. Regular assessments of vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies will be necessary to track the patient's progress and adjust treatment accordingly.
